DataElement.preferredDefinition: the absence or presence of distant metastases from colorectal cancer as determined prior to treatment based on evidence obtained from clinical assessment parameters (physical examination, imaging, endoscopy, biopsy, surgical exploration, etc.).

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Information related to clinlcal M stage of a colorectal tumor.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: (ko-lo-REK-tul) Having to do with the colon or the rectum.:(NEE-o-PLAY-zha) Abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth.

Concepts.definition: Relating to the colon and rectum, or to the entire large bowel.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: Having to do with the examination and treatment of patients.:One criteria of the TMN staging system.  M refers to the presence of metastasis.

Concepts.definition: Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation.  The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity.
One criteria of the TNM staging system. M refers to the presence of metastasis.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 8-28-19 ownership transfer approved by CTEP/B.Campbell; tmt.

ValueDomain.preferredName: American Joint Committee on Cancer V7 Colorectal Tumor M Stage
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the M (metastasis) stage for a colorectal tumor as defined by the AJCC Cancer Staging Manual, 7th Ed.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Metastases in more than one organ/site or the peritoneum

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Metastases in more than one organ/site or the peritoneum
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Metastases in more than one organ/site or the peritoneum

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Metastasis confined to one organ or site (e.g., liver, lung, ovary, non-regional node)

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Metastasis confined to one organ or site (e.g., liver, lung, ovary, non-regional node)
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Metastasis confined to one organ or site (e.g., liver, lung, ovary, non-regional node)
Refers to cancer that has spread from the original (primary) tumor to distant organs or distant lymph nodes.

Concepts.definition: A biological process that involves the transfer and growth of cancer cells from the site of the primary tumor. Relocation of malignant cells during metastasis can be restricted to movement within a specific tissue/organ or may entail migration to a distal locus within the body. This phenotype is a characteristic of all malignant tumors.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No clinical or radiographic evidence of distant metastases

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: American Joint Committee on Cancer Stage
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.:The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.
The extent of a cancer in the body.
